content.webTitle: Wall Street shrugs off losses with 'relief rally'

fields.headline: Wall Street shrugs off losses with 'relief rally'
fields.bodyText: Wall Street rallied yesterday after four straight days of losses, easing fears that world markets could be on the brink of a downturn. Benign economic data in the United States allowed investors to focus on the flood of first quarter earnings reported. Many, with the notable exception of General Motors, provided the comfort markets were looking for. In early afternoon trading the blue-chip Dow Jones index was 67.39 points higher at 10138.64. The Nasdaq market, home to many technology stocks, was up 16.19 points at 1929.11. Europe also took encouragement from the US. The FTSE 100 closed 28.5 points higher at 4,855.6, Germany's benchmark Dax-30 index was 0.1% higher and the key Paris index 0.3% better. The Dow suffered a 420-point loss in the final three days of last week amid fears that the American economy was beginning to falter. It slipped another 16 points on Monday as investors searched company earnings for clues on the economy, with little apparent success. Producer price data in the US yesterday eased worries about faster increases in interest rates, hinted at recently by the federal reserve. The US labour department reported only a 0.1% gain in prices during March, excluding energy and food. Texas Instruments, the world's largest maker of chips for mobile phones, helped lift sentiment with results after the close on Monday night. It reported a 12% gain in profits to $411m (£214m) and said the pace of demand was picking up. The shares were trading 6% higher at $24.26. Other key tech stocks, Intel and Yahoo! were due to report last night. "The market is having a relief rally in reaction to decent earnings news, or at least news that isn't significantly bad," said Jay Finkel, senior equity trader with broker Lord Abbett. Lucent Technologies said second quarter earnings grew more than fourfold. It was the most actively traded stock on Wall Street, rising 8.5%. EMC, the maker of data storage computers and software, said income had nearly doubled and orders picked up in March. Its shares were $1.57 higher at $13.04. Merrill Lynch reported a 3% fall in first-quarter profits to $1.2bn and said the difficult environment in March had accelerated in April. The figures beat expectations and the bank cheered investors by announcing a $4bn share buyback. The bank was trading 86 cents higher at $54.10. The smaller Wells Fargo and US Bancorp both reported record quarterly earnings. Johnson & Johnson beat Wall Street forecasts. Viacom, the media conglomerate that owns MTV, reported a 15% jump in the first three months to $508m, after stripping out a tax gain last year. Revenues were 5% higher at $5.6bn on the back of a strong performance from cable networks. Taser, the stun-gun maker, posted a sharp drop in first quarter earnings after the controversy raging over the safety of its weapons. Profits were $168,000 in the first three months, compared with $3.6m a year ago. The shares fell 10 cents to $7.87 in mid-day trade. They reached a high of $32.59 in December. Oil prices moved higher after two weeks of falls. In New York a barrel of light crude was worth $51.60, up $1.23.
